abstract.p: The implementation of the Hill estimator, which estimates the heaviness of the tail of a distribution, requires a choice of the number of extreme observations in the tails, r, from a sample of size n, where 2 ≤ r + 1 ≤ n. This article is concerned with a robust procedure of choosing an optimal r. Thus, an estimation procedure, δ <sub>s</sub>, based on the idea of spacing statistics, H<sup>(r)</sup>, is developed. The proposed decision rule for choosing r under the squared error loss is found to be a simple function of the sample size. The proposed rule is then illustrated across a wide range of data, including insurance claims, currency exchange rate returns, and city size.
